comments.content: ABD is correct.. assm will not fix the lack of space in data file issue..

choices.A: altering the data file associated with the SMD tablespace to grow automatically
choices.B: adding a data file to the SMD tablespace, provided the tablespace has not reached its maximum number of file
choices.C: changing segment space management for the SMD tablespace to automatic
choices.E: increasing the space quota on the SMD tablespace for the SH user, provided the files have not yet reached their maximum size
choices.D: resizing the data file associated with the SMD tablespace to make it larger, provided all data files have not yet reached their maximum size

questions.question_text:
SMD is a smallfile locally managed tablespace with manual segment space management.
The SH user receives the following error while inserting data into the sales table:
//IMG//

Which three actions can be taken to enable the user to insert data? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Answer is CD. 
(two files)

C,D are correct. The errors in this question are frustrating.

The source for this question even references required tasks post-ASM upgrade on a single-instance. The question would clearly distinguish this so the given "answers" are incorrect. 

The real question states, "choose two" and not "choose three". Another source I have found starts with "Which files must you copy from the Oracle home of the database" so even the beginning of this question is incorrect. 

As stated in another comment, if the question asks "don't need to copy" then the given answers would be correct. 

However, single-instance upgrade on a file system requires copying of both the init parameter file and the password file to the new Oracle home.
I think the question is 'don't need to copy'

comments.content: the real question is choose two not three

questions.question_text: Which two files must you copy from the Oracle home of the database that is being upgraded to the new Oracle home for Oracle Database 12c? (Choose three.)
Identify three valid options for adding a pluggable database (PDB) to an existing multitenant container database (CDB).
questions.answer_description:
Use the CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement to create a pluggable database (PDB).
This statement enables you to perform the following tasks:
* (A) Create a PDB by using the seed as a template
Use the create_pdb_from_seed clause to create a PDB by using the seed in the multitenant container database (CDB) as a template. The files associated with the seed are copied to a new location and the copied files are then associated with the new PDB.
* (C) Create a PDB by cloning an existing PDB
Use the create_pdb_clone clause to create a PDB by copying an existing PDB (the source PDB) and then plugging the copy into the CDB. The files associated with the source PDB are copied to a new location and the copied files are associated with the new PDB. This operation is called cloning a PDB.
The source PDB can be plugged in or unplugged. If plugged in, then the source PDB can be in the same CDB or in a remote CDB. If the source PDB is in a remote CDB, then a database link is used to connect to the remote CDB and copy the files.
* Create a PDB by plugging an unplugged PDB or a non-CDB into a CDB
Use the create_pdb_from_xml clause to plug an unplugged PDB or a non-CDB into a CDB, using an XML metadata file.

choices.C: Use the DBMS_PDB package to clone an existing PDB.
choices.E: Use the DBMS_PDB package to plug an Oracle 11 g Release 2 (11.2.0.3.0) non-CDB database into an existing CDB.
choices.D: Use the DBMS_PDB package to plug an Oracle 12c non-CDB database into an existing CDB.
choices.B: Use the CREATE DATABASE . . . ENABLE PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement to provision a PDB by copying file from the SEED.
choices.A: Use the CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement to create a PDB using the files from the SEED.

discussion.content:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/sutil/oracle-sql-loader-express-mode.html#GUID-8C235861-2A8B-4196-9705-E6FFED0C0C99

SQL Loaded Express mode doesn't need a control file but uses the table column definition in ALL_TAB_COLUMNS to process the load.

DE confirmed.

confirmed.

NOT A – contradicted with D.
NOT B – In express mode, a SQL*Loader control file is not used.
NOT C – If no data file is specified, then it looks for a file named table-
name.dat in the current directory.

D – If you activate SQL*Loader express mode by specifying only the TABLE
parameter, then SQL*Loader uses default settings for a number of other
parameters.
E – For some errors, SQL*Loader express mode automatically switches from the
default external tables load method to direct path load. An example of when
this might occur would be if a privilege violation caused the CREATE
DIRECTORY SQL command to fail.

questions.question_text:
In your Oracle 12c database, you invoke SQL *Loader Express Mode command to load data:
$> sqlldr hr/hr table=employees
Which two statements are true about this command? (Choose two.)

choices.C: It fails because the SQL *Loader data file location is not specified.
choices.B: It fails because the SQL *Loader control file location is not specified.
choices.E: It succeeds even if the HR user does not have the CREATE DIRECTORY privilege.
choices.D: It succeeds with default settings if the EMPLOYEES table belonging to the HR schema is already defined in the database.
choices.A: It succeeds and creates the EMPLOYEES table in the HR schema if the table does not exist.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
A level 0 incremental backup, which is the base for subsequent incremental backups, copies all blocks containing data, backing the datafile up into a backup set just as a full backup would. 
A level 1 incremental backup can be either of the following types:

A differential backup, which backs up all blocks changed after the most recent incremental backup at level 1 or 0

A cumulative backup, which backs up all blocks changed after the most recent incremental backup at level 0

comments.content:
Theoretically you're right but if you see the question, level 0 is happening on Sunday followed by Level 1 cumulative on Monday. The subsequent level 1 differential backups will have data changed since last cumulative level 1 backup, hence option E is incorrect for this scenario. All differential backups in this backup schedule will have changes since last level 1 backup only. 
If there was level 1 differential backup taken on Monday, then option E would be correct as it is followed by the level 0 backup on Sunday.
So option ACD is right here.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDE
A differential backup, which backs up all blocks changed after the most recent incremental backup at level 1 or 0. A cumulative backup, which backs up all blocks changed after the most recent incremental backup at level 0.

questions.question_text:
Backup requirements for a database:
* Level 0 backup on Sunday
* Cumulative incremental level 1 backup on Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday
* Differential incremental level 1 backup on Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday
Which three statements are true about the strategy? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Level 0 backup on Sunday contains all the blocks that have been changed since the last level 1 backup.
choices.A: Level 0 backup on Sunday contains all the blocks that have been formatted.
choices.C: Level 1 backup on Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday contains all the blocks that have been changed since the last level 1 backup.
choices.D: Level 1 backup on Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday contains all the blocks that have been changed since the last level 0 backup.
choices.E: Level 1 backup on Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday contains all the blocks that have been changed since the last level 0 backup.
